description:
Drosophila subobscura is a species of fruit fly that belongs to the family Drosophilidae. It is a member of the obscura group within the Drosophila genus. Drosophila subobscura is native to Europe and North Africa, and it has been introduced to various parts of the world, including the Americas and Australia.

Drosophila subobscura is a small insect, typically measuring around 2-3 millimeters in length. It has a brown or grayish-brown body with dark-colored legs and wings. The species is characterized by its unique chromosomal structure, which includes five pairs of autosomes and one pair of sex chromosomes (X and Y).

Drosophila subobscura is widely used as a model organism in genetics and evolutionary biology research. Its chromosomal inversion polymorphisms, which are changes in the arrangement of genetic material within chromosomes, have been extensively studied to understand the mechanisms of adaptation and population dynamics. The species has also been used to investigate topics such as circadian rhythms, behavior, and the effects of environmental factors on genetic variation.

Due to its widespread distribution and adaptability, Drosophila subobscura has become an important model organism for understanding the evolutionary processes that shape species diversity and adaptation in the Drosophila genus.
